data.text: Contents
Assessment of Risk - Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessments ........................................... 17
Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessments for adult patients .................................................. 17
Appendix 4: Click here for European Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel pressure ulcer
Introduction

This policy provides information and guidance to Registered Nurses, Healthcare Assistants, Allied Health professionals and Medical staff to ensure there is a safe and consistent approach to the assessment, prevention and management of Pressure Ulcers Trust wide.

Pressure ulcer prevention and management is a fundamental aspect of patient care. In the Hospital setting pressure ulcers can affect people of any age and can have a profound impact on the overall wellbeing of patients both emotionally and related to quality of life issues. They are also a significant part of NHS costs; treating pressure ulcers cost the NHS more than £1.4 million per day (NHS Improvement 2018).
Pressure ulcer prevention is of extreme importance in the continual drive to improve quality of care, reduce harm and improve the patient experience.
Scope

This policy relates to all patients admitted to the Trust who are identified as being at risk of pressure ulcer development, have pre-existing pressure ulcers, and those who develop a pressure ulcer whilst an inpatient within the Trust.
All Staff working within the Trust are expected to adhere to this policy.
This policy is relevant to
Emergency Care Departments;
Assessments units
Out-patient Departments
In-patient facilities / Units / Wards;
Operating Theatres/day theatres.
The Policy is relevant for:
Nursing and Health Care Assistants
Theatre staff
MEMs staff
Medical Equipment Training Co-ordinators
Manual Handling Teams
Medical staff
Occupational Therapists
Physiotherapists
Falls Team
Tissue Viability Team
Purpose

The purpose of this policy is raise awareness amongst staff about the importance and relevance of their role in the delivery of safe and effective pressure ulcer care. This includes aware of risks associated with pressure ulcer development, appropriate management of these risks including the risk assessment process
and incident reporting, and to facilitate the implementation of best practice pressure ulcer care and management.
The policy provides guidance on the actions all clinical staff should take to:
Ensure patients admitted to the Trust with existing pressure ulcers are appropriately assessed, and pressure ulcer related care pathways are adhered to.
Identify patients through the admission process who are at risk of developing pressure ulcers, and ensure appropriate care pathways are adhered to.
Ensure the appropriate and timely care of patients following the identification of a pressure ulcer.
Provide pressure ulcer care in line with best practice guidelines
This policy is underpinned by National Institute Clinical Excellence Pressure Ulcer Guidelines (2014), NHS Improvement (2018), and European Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel (EPUAP) (2019) Guidelines.
Definitions

table_items.text: A pressure ulcer will be defined as: “localised damage to the skin and/or underlying tissue, usually over a bony prominence (or related to a medical or other device), resulting from sustained pressure (including pressure associated with shear). The damage can be present as intact skin or an open ulcer and may be painful”. (NHS Improvement 2018). Although pressure ulcers can occur over any bony prominence, the most common sites for pressure ulcer development are: Sacrum, lower back and buttocks Heels Hips Back of the head and ears Elbows (Gefen 2017)

This type of pressure ulcer will be defined as ones that “result from the use of devices designed and applied for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. ¬The resultant pressure injury generally conforms to the pattern or shape of the device”. This definition includes objects such as spectacles and other devices without a medical purpose (NPUAP 2015; NHS I 2018).

A pressure ulcer found on mucous membranes with a history of a medical device in use at the location of the ulcer. Mucosal tissues are especially vulnerable to pressure from medical devices, such as nasal cannula, endotracheal tubes, bite blocks, orogastric and
nasogastric tubes, urinary catheters and faecal containment devices.

This is defined as “Purple or maroon localized area of discoloured intact skin or blood-filled blister due to damage of underlying soft tissue from pressure and/or shear. The area may be preceded by tissue that is painful, firm, mushy, boggy, warmer or cooler as compared to adjacent tissue” (EPUAP 2014).
Temperature and humidity between the patient and the surface they are sitting or lying on (Fletcher 2020).

MASD is the umbrella term for incontinence associated dermatitis, periwound, intertriginous and peristomal dermatitis. Excessive moisture and the associated chemical irritants can cause different levels of skin damage, from persistent redness, to areas of skin loss. Incontinence Associated Dermatitis (IAD) is caused by urine and/or faeces and perspiration which is continuously in contact with the patients' skin on their perineum, buttocks, groins, inner thighs, natal cleft, skin folds. This can also occur where skin is in contact with skin. Correctly identifying IAD from a pressure ulcer can be difficult. Appendix 1 provides a guide to support correct identification of IAD.
This is considered to be a new pressure ulcer which is acquired within the Trust that was not present on admission but was observed within the current episode of care.

A pressure ulcer that is present on admission to the Trust, and was first observed during the skin assessment which was undertaken during the admission process within the Trust regardless of where this took place at the time of the admission (e.g. Accident and Emergency Department, out-patient department or a Ward).
Within the Trust the term ‘lapses in care' will replace the terms avoidable and unavoidable in relation to Hospital acquired pressure ulcers.

Extrinsic and Intrinsic factors - for a pressure ulcer caused primarily by body weight forces: Extrinsic factors: Pressure and Shear are the main extrinsic factors. See Appendix 2 for an explanation of pressure and shear. High pressure over bony prominences for a short period of time and low pressure over bony prominences for a long period of time are equally damaging. To lessen the patient's risk of developing a pressure ulcer, it is important to reduce the time and the amount of pressure the patient is exposed to. If damage not associated with pressure, friction or shear is noted, other possible causes need to be identified, such as epidermal stripping due to traumatic removal of tapes or dressings, eczematous skin, sweat or incontinence. Intrinsic factors: See Appendix 3 for a list of intrinsic factors Friction: contributes to shear but is not a direct cause of pressure ulceration on its own.
Causes of device related pressure ulcers (DRPU)

The main cause of this pressure damage is attributed to localised friction or pressure on the soft tissue under or around the device. It is not necessarily associated with a bony prominence. The areas most at risk of device related pressure damage are Around the site where the device is inserted Where the device is placed The mucosal lining
Factors that place a patient at risk of developing a DRPU

The patient may be unable to sense / feel the device and the pressure, friction and shear on their skin may be unable to reposition themselves or the device Bariatric patients should be regarded as being at high risk The length of time the device is in situ may be a factor if required over an extended period of time Securing the device too tightly Being nursed in the prone position Comorbidities that limit tolerance to mechanical loads on vulnerable skin, and soft tissue sites which may be affected by uncontrolled oedema or unfavourable or poorly managed local tissue microclimate. Standard generic design of a device and limited range of available sizes that may not necessarily fit the patient well or properly. Devices are often made from very stiff materials that do not conform well to tissue shape. This can cause localised skin distortions when the device interacts with skin and underlying soft tissue Lack of clinician awareness of the importance of repositioning, offloading, rotating devices or correctly fitting or securing the devices
Application of direct pressure to the mucosal membrane attributed to use of a device
Factors that place a patient at risk of developing a device related mucosal pressure ulcer:

Use of a medical device on an area of the body lined with mucosal tissue Lack of repositioning the device Length of time the device is required Fixing the device too tightly Poorly fitting, or poorly secured device The physical components of the device, i.e. stiff or rigid materials Being nursed in the prone position

Heels are the second most common site for pressure ulcers. They are particularly at risk from pressure damage due to their anatomy and require additional protection. The heel's posterior aspect has a thin layer of fat and skin, and a poor arterial blood supply via the calcaneal and peroneal arteries. It is not well adapted to withstand high pressure when a patient is supine; pressure from the weight of the lower limb is concentrated on the small area of the posterior aspect of the calcaneum. Prolonged pressure to this area can quickly lead to ischaemia. Patient particularly at risk of developing a heel pressure ulcer are: Fracture Neck of Femur Stroke Diabetes End of Life Reduced/absent sensation to their feet; Peripheral vascular disease Unable to reposition lower limb / heel independently; Existing heel pressure damage

Waterlow 20 or above. Complete removal of local pressure is central to the prevention and management of heel pressure ulceration. Additional protection is required, and significantly reduced incidence of heel pressure ulceration has been shown to be associated with the use of appropriate pressure relieving / reducing equipment.

Within the Trust pressure ulcers will be classified in line with the EPUAP classification system (2019); (see Appendix 4). Pressure ulcers should not be reverse categorised, for example, a category 4 pressure ulcer does not become a category 3 as it heals; it should be described as a healing category 4 pressure ulcer. Non-Blanching erythema should be documented as such and the term category 1 used. The term ‘red' or ‘redness' should be avoided unless it is qualified as non-blanching or blanching erythema. Unstageable pressure ulcers should be reviewed on a weekly basis to help identify a definitive category; note that this may not occur during the inpatient episode of care. This review will be undertaken by the Tissue Viability Team either via direct patient assessment or review of medical photography. Deep tissue injuries should be reviewed on a weekly basis to enable a category to be identified if / when the injury evolves during the episode of care as an in-patient stay. This will be undertaken by the Tissue Viability Team either via direct patient assessment or review of medical photography. Follow the DTI pathway (Appendix 6). See Appendix 5 for explanation of DTI. Where there is a combined pressure ulcer with MASD / IAD report based on pressure ulcer category.
Identify a device related pressure ulcer using the letter (d) after the designated category.

Mucosal pressure ulcers cannot be categorised in line with EPUAP categorisation; the tissue does not have the same layers as the skin therefore categorise as mucosal (do not attach any other category to it).

Use Datix Incident Reporting system to report, category 1, 2, 3, 4, unstageable pressure ulcers, deep tissue injury and mucosal pressure ulcer. Complete a Datix Incident Report for each separate pressure ulcer. Identify via Datix Incident Report if inherited or Hospital Acquired via the category “Pressure Ulcer” and appropriate sub category followed by the pressure ulcer category. For device related pressure ulcer and mucosal pressure ulcer select the correct reporting category to identify the pressure damage. Use Datix Incident Reporting system to report Moisture Associated Skin Damage. Update Datix Incident Report if a pressure ulcer status deteriorates or a
Hospital Acquired Pressure Ulcer investigation process

Hospital acquired pressure ulcer category 2, 3, 4 and unstageable will be investigated via the Trust's Root Cause Analysis (RCA) process. If a patient has multiple hospital acquired pressure ulcers a separate RCA template does not need to be completed for each pressure ulcer; the Harm Free Care team will advise the Ward how to proceed. The weekly Harm Free Care Pressure Ulcer Panel will review completed RCA templates and determine: if lapses in care are identified level of harm to be attributed to the pressure ulcer incident if Safeguarding threshold is met and Safeguarding Team to action accordingly if Serious Incident threshold is met and to proceed to Executive Review Group for review and decision. The RCA process is not triggered for a Hospital acquired deep tissue injury. If the damage evolves to category 2,3,4, or unstageable during the hospital admission the Datix Incident Report must be updated to reflect this and the RCA process is instigated.

data.text: Duties
The Trust Board / Executive

Mid  and  South  Essex  NHS  Foundation  Trust  (‘the  Trust')  recognises  the occurrence of a hospital acquired pressure ulcer is an adverse clinical event, but the Trust also acknowledges that not all pressure ulcers are preventable. By recording incidents and auditing practice and identifying where there have been lapses in care the number of hospital acquired pressure ulcers can be minimised. The Trust is responsible for:
Robust reporting of pressure ulcers that are acquired within Trust services and present on admission; this will be in line with recommendations set out by NHS Improvement documentation (2018)
Counting and reporting all moisture associated skin damage
Providing relevant pressure ulcer training and education for clinical staff, using a database to record attendance accordingly

Providing specialist pressure relieving equipment for pressure ulcer prevention and management, and ensuring that there is a clear record of safety checks and decontamination process for audit purposes.
Providing specialist education and emotional support for staff, patients and their relatives and carers where appropriate to do so

Providing support and advice to Registered Nurses and Medical staff where required to ensure patients receive appropriate pressure ulcer prevention and care including appropriate care planning and documentation.
The Chief Executive
Cascade MSE Group objectives
The Chief Nurse

As Executive Lead for Harm Free Care, the Chief Nurse is responsible for ensuring that the Trust Board / Executive is aware of, and discharges its statutory duties in relation to pressure ulcer prevention and management.

Director of Nursing (With MSE Responsibility for Harm Free Care)  Responsible for ensuring the implementation and delivery of policies and procedures relating to Trust wide pressure ulcer prevention and management including:
Oversight of pressure ulcer practice within the MSE structure.

Monitoring the effectiveness of the Harm Free Care process and provide assurance to the Board, via the Chief Nurse, that the Trust is meeting its duty in relation to delivery of safe and effective pressure ulcer care.
Director of Nursing (at each site)

Responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non- medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Associate Director for Harm Free Care (Group Role)  Responsible for:

Development and leadership of a robust Trust wide pressure ulcer reporting and investigating process ensuring where lapses in care for Hospital acquired pressure ulcers are identified learning is shared across the Trust and robust actions plans are in place.
Ensuring the Serious Incident process is triggered and adhered to if the threshold is met

To lead on collaborative working practices with Clinical Commission Group partners to ensure a seamless approach to accurate reporting of pressure ulcers present on admission to the Trust and those deemed to be Hospital Acquired
Leading a robust culture of Harm Free Care, directed through the approved Trust Harm free Care reporting structure to Patient Safety and Quality Committees.
Tissue Viability Nurse Specialist Team Lead Responsible for:
Promoting the early accurate identification and management of pressure ulcers where safeguarding concerns are identified via the safeguarding decision tool.
Ensuring that national and local recommendations from emergent pressure ulcer work are implemented across the Trust and are included within its policies and practice

Analyse pressure ulcer data, identifying trends, highlighting the need for improvement where appropriate to do so and working with the clinical teams to achieve this. Providing pressure ulcer data reports to the Oversight Committee as required
The Tissue Viability Nurse Specialist Team:
Is responsible for providing advice and support to clinicians within the Trust in relation to pressure ulcer prevention and management.
Is a resource to all members of the multi-disciplinary team within the Trust.
As such they will respond to educational and training needs identified by staff, and patients, and deliver the appropriate training to meet these needs.
Will support clinical staff with the implementation of agreed pathways of care
Will support the reduction of the incidence of hospital acquired pressure ulcers
Will lead the implementation and development of the pressure ulcer policy across the Trust, ensuring the policy is adhered to through consultation and audit.

Provide guidance regarding the management of complex patients with pressure ulcer related problems, and provide specialist assessment and advice on the appropriate management including effective risk prevention strategies and implementation of appropriate pressure relieving equipment.
Ensure a pressure ulcer training programme is in place to facilitate Trust wide
learning
Directors of Nursing, Heads of Nursing, Matrons, Ward Sisters/ Charge Nurses, Allied Health Professionals, Team Leaders and all Health Professionals
Responsible for:
ensuring steps are taken to implement the requirements of Trust policies and management guidelines

ensuring clinical staff receive training in pressure ulcer prevention and safe use of pressure relieving equipment in accordance with the Trust's Training Needs Analysis, and in the use of any equipment required to comply with this policy.
following up all incidents associated with pressure ulcers to identify their cause and review the control measures in place.
All Employees
All staff involved in the care of patients who are 'at risk' of developing, or who have, a pressure ulcer must:
Be aware of content in this policy and actions required to be taken that arise from it

Recognise the importance of undertaking and documenting pressure ulcer risk assessments, and the implementation and documentation of appropriate preventative and management pressure ulcer care pathways arising from this
Attend pressure ulcer training and maintain competency in pressure ulcer risk assessment, delivery of best practice pressure ulcer care and appropriate care planning.
Understand their role and responsibility when ordering pressure relieving equipment
Understand the roles of the multi-disciplinary team in pressure ulcer prevention and management
Recognise and support patients and their relatives and carers who play a vital role in the prevention of pressure ulcers
Maintain accurate pressure ulcer documentation in accordance with Trust Policy

Report accurately and in a timely manner the occurrence of all category 1, 2, 3, 4, unstageable pressure ulcers and deep tissue injuries inherited and Hospital acquired and moisture associated skin damage inherited and Hospital acquired
Be aware of, and draw upon, the ‘'aSSKINg' pathway for the prevention and management of pressure ulcers (Appendix 7).
Maintain and update knowledge of appropriate wound dressing selection and appropriate pressure ulcer treatment regimes where appropriate
Participate in audit/benchmarking process as required.
Patient Safety & Quality Committee

The committee receive a quarterly report from Tissue Viability on all matters relating to the Trust's Pressure Ulcer Prevention Strategy together with appropriate risk control measures to eliminate or reduce any identified pressure ulcer risks. The group will take any action it feels appropriate in the light of that received report.
Harm Free Care Pressure Ulcer Panel Responsible for:
promotion of the Pressure Ulcer Prevention agenda in line with national and local guidelines.
on-going monitoring of all pressure ulcers inherited (present on admission) and hospital acquired that are reported within the Trust.

providing a professional investigation of all Hospital acquired pressure ulcers category 2 and above including mucosal pressure ulcers via the weekly Harm Free Care Panel process; this includes ensuring incident outcomes and lessons learnt are shared effectively Trust wide
Triggering the Serious Incident process where the threshold is met
Maintaining a database of all Hospital acquired deep tissue injuries
Process – Pressure Ulcer prevention
The ‘aSSKINg' framework is a National tool that underpins local pressure ulcer prevention and management. The elements of the framework are:
Assess risk
Skin Inspection
Support surface - Use of pressure relieving or redistributing equipment Keep moving - Positioning and repositioning
Incontinence management
Nutrition and hydration
Giving information
The aSSKINg framework should be adhered to by all Trust staff who provide any aspect of pressure area care / interventions. (Appendix 7).

Within the Trust all patients should have a multi-disciplinary team approach to their pressure ulcer prevention or treatment. Patients with identified risks factors may require referral to other members of the multi-disciplinary team where appropriate.
The Trust's pressure ulcer pathway is set out in Appendix 8
Assessment of Risk - Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessments

Patients Vulnerable to Pressure ulcers: All individuals are potentially at risk of developing a pressure ulcer. However, they are more likely to occur in people who are seriously ill, have a neurological condition, impaired mobility, poor posture or a deformity, compromised skin or who are malnourished. (See Appendix 9).
Undertake and document the outcome of the following for all patients:
Pressure Ulcer risk assessment
Nutritional risk assessment
Use the Risk Assessment tools as an adjunct to clinical judgement and not as a tool in isolation from other clinical features.
Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessments for adult patients
Patients seen in Emergency Department
8.1.1 Complete the skin assessment within 1 hour of admission and the Anderson screening tool within 4 hours of admission to the Department
All adult in-patients Wards, Critical Care and High Dependency Unit
8.2.1  Complete the Waterlow Risk assessment tool within 6 hours of a patient being admitted to a Ward / Critical Care and High Dependency Unit by a Registered Nurse.
Maternity
8.3.1  Complete the Waterlow Risk Assessment tool (note Southend site uses an adapted version at present) within 6 hours of a patient being admitted to the Trust by a Midwife.
Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessments for Paediatrics and Neonates
Paediatrics
9.1.1 Complete the Glamorgan risk assessment tool within 6 hours
Neonates
9.2.1  Complete the Neonate Risk Assessment tool within 6 hours of a patient being admitted to the Trust by an appropriately trained Registered Nurse.
Nutritional Risk Assessment tool

9.3.1  Completed by an appropriately trained Registered Nurse. Any actions required as an outcome of the assessment must be undertaken including referral and input from the Dietetics Team (see section Nutrition page 29 below).
Moving and Handing Assessment

Pressure ulcers can develop from using manual handling devices. Undertake a comprehensive risk assessment of a moving and handling task as this will identify any hazards posed by the activity (see appendix 21).
The safe use of equipment involves achieving the transfer as intended and preventing unnecessary injury to patient in the process. Specialist advice can be sought from the Manual Handling Team.
Ensure all other risk assessments (e.g. Falls risk assessment) are completed in a timely manner and document the outcome in the patient's clinical record and action accordingly.
Patients with medical devices in situ
Have a high level of awareness and vigilance around management of the skin under and around the devices, the anatomical location of the devices, and the physical form of the device itself.
Have an awareness of any risk associated with the device
Document the device(s) that are in situ
Adhere to the device related pressure ulcer pathway (use of foamlite dressing) for patients requiring long term oxygen therapy (Appendix 10).
Reassess Risk Assessments
Reassess if there:
Is a change in the patient's medical condition or circumstances
on transfer to another Ward
at least weekly as a minimum
Documentation
Document the outcome of all pressure ulcer related risk assessments in the patient's records.
Skin Inspection

Assess the patient's skin whilst in the Emergency Department, and within 6 hours of admission to the in-patient Ward. Document and date the outcome of the skin assessment on the body map in the patient records.

Thereafter, all patients should either have, or be offered a skin inspection at least daily throughout their hospital stay and twice daily if a pressure ulcer is present (but recognising for critically ill patients this frequency may be adjusted according to their condition).
Encourage patients where ever possible, following education, to inspect their own skin.
If a patient is unable to inspect their own skin, this should be carried out for them.
Remove anti-embolism stockings or sequential circumferential device (SCDs) at least daily to undertake a thorough skin assessment. Document the outcome.
If required use a mirror to help check the patient's skin integrity particularly on the heels if the skin cannot be fully visualised during the inspection.
Bariatric patients
Be aware that pressure damage may occur under skin folds and from pressure across the buttocks and areas of high adipose tissue concentration.
Undertaking a skin inspection
During a skin inspection the following should be looked for:
Skin appearance
persistent reddened or purple areas,
blisters or broken areas
existing pressure damage
areas that look purple or bruised
skin tears or rashes
Skin appearance over the bony prominences:
Non blanching erythema
Moisture – incontinence, sweating, wound fluid.
Texture - dry, flaky, cracked skin; skin which feels harder or boggy compared to the surrounding skin
Temperature changes
Pain or discomfort
Recognising pressure ulcers in patients with darker skin tones

Detecting category 1 pressure ulcer, and a deep tissue injury in patients with darker skin tones is challenging. Skin pigmentation can mask visual indications of erythema and category 1 and deep tissue injury.
Skin assessment is key and should take into consideration:
Localised pain
Past history of pressure damage
High Waterlow score
Purple / blue discolouration to the skin
Purple hue where ischaemia is present
Temperature change: Local heat (inflammatory response) or skin cooling (devitalisation)
Oedema with taut, shiny skin
Change of skin texture
Alteration in sensation in response to inflammation or ischaemia
Induration
soft and boggy
COVID Lesions vs Pressure Ulcer

Covid-19 skin injuries mimic the appearance of deep tissue pressure injuries, especially when they occur over tissue exposed to pressure and/or shear (e.g. sacrum, buttocks, and heels), or under medical devices. If the blood vessels are significantly or fully occluded, then adequate reperfusion is not achievable even in the presence of reasonable repositioning and turning of the patient and the use of appropriate support surfaces.
See Appendix  for differentiation between a suspected Covid 19 lesion and a pressure ulcer.
Skin Inspection under a medical device

Inspect the skin under and around medical devices 2 hourly where ever possible. More frequent assessment will be required for high-risk patients. Frequency may vary for patients nursed in the prone position or where the device cannot be lifted or repositioned easily and will depend on individual patient circumstances.
Pay special attention where localised oedema is present under the device inspection.
If a nasogastric tube is in situ change the tapes at least daily and inspect the skin to the entrance of the nose and the lining at each tape change. Use a torch to check inside the nose.
Change endotrachael ties twice daily. Inspect the skin under the ties at each change.
Skin Inspection for the patient in the prone position
Undertake skin inspection before and after the patient is placed in the prone position. Document the outcome in the patient's clinical record. Adhere to the Prone SOP.
Documentation
Document the outcome of the skin assessment in the patient record and on the site specific Care Round / SSKIN documentation in line with care instructions on the documentation.
Update the body map if a pressure ulcer is identified.
Complete Datix incident report as required: if a new pressure ulcer is identified or an existing pressure ulcer has deteriorated and has been re-categorised.
Document in the patient's notes if it is not possible to check under a medical device.
Document if a patient declines skin inspection
Support Surface: Pressure Relieving Equipment  Emergency Department

Mattresses on the Emergency Department trolley will be of a high specification foam. Where a patient is assessed as being at high risk of developing pressure ulcers, or has a pressure ulcer(s), and admission to a Ward is delayed, transfer to an appropriate bed, and as a minimum a high specification foam mattress, and request a full dynamic replacement mattress in line with site specific pressure relieving equipment selection criteria.
In-patients
All patients (adults and children) admitted to the Trust will have access as a minimum to a high specification foam replacement mattress.

Ensure patients with a pressure ulcer have 24 hour access to appropriate pressure relieving equipment (mattress and, if required, cushion in line with the Trust pressure relieving equipment selection criteria).

Provide an appropriate pressure relieving mattress and cushion for each patient as an outcome of the pressure ulcer risk assessment, and in line with the pressure relieving equipment selection criteria (Appendix 12).

Provide a full dynamic replacement mattress for adult patients who cannot reposition independently or with a Waterlow score 20+ and/or with multiple category 2 pressure ulcers, Category 3, 4 unstageable pressure ulcer or a deep tissue injury (DTI), and / or unless contraindicated. Always combine decision with clinical judgement.
Document rationale for equipment selection in the patient records including if mattress / cushion type selected differs from the pressure relieving equipment selection criteria.
Ensure the recommended weight range for the mattress is appropriate for the patient
DO NOT USE ring or donut-shaped devices as a pressure relieving surface.
Keep the number of layers between a patient's skin and support surface to a minimum.
Critical Care
All patients are nursed on a dynamic alternating mattress unless contraindicated by their clinical condition e.g. static foam for unstable spinal injury, or patient choice.
Spinal Cord Injury

Provide the support surface most appropriate for the patient's injury and comfort noting that this may not be a full dynamic alternating mattress. (Refer to the site specific pressure relieving equipment selection criteria)

Provide a high specification static foam mattress until the patient's Consultant has confirmed the spinal cord is stable (Atmos Air or powered hybrid are contra- indicated). Once confirmed as stable, and if required as outcome of Waterlow risk assessment, individual patient skin assessment, and pressure ulcer status, and clinical judgement request and install a full dynamic replacement mattress in line with the pressure relieving equipment selection criteria (Appendix 12).
Bariatric Patients
Ensure the bed and mattress (and cushion if required) is appropriate for the patient's size and weight.
Labour Ward - Central Delivery Suite
Ensure a high specification foam mattress is used on the delivery bed.
Paediatrics
Prior to providing a dynamic replacement mattress system ensure the child cannot sink into gaps created by deflated cells.
Ensure the lower weight restriction of the mattress/cushion is appropriate for the child.
Be aware that many dynamic pressure mattresses have a permanently inflated head end which may place the occiput at risk in young children.
Neonates
Neonates will have access to a high specification foam in a cot.
In an incubator a foam base mattress must be in place.
Consider the use of Repose nest for neonates assessed as high risk of pressure ulcer development.
Patient at risk of falls

When considering the use of dynamic pressure relieving equipment for a patient at risk of falls from the bed / or chair, where the dynamic action of the mattress may increase the risk of a fall, carefully consider the risk / benefit of using this equipment type. Clearly document rationale for decision in the patient record.
Use of bed safety rails and bed rail bumpers
If a patient requires bed rails this must be based on the outcome of a bed safety rail assessment. This must be clearly documented in the patient record and the need reviewed on change of condition.
If bed rails are required as the outcome of assessment ensure the mattress does not elevate the individual to an unsafe height in relation to them.
Refer to the bed rail policy for appropriate use of bed rails and bumpers.
Using heel zone function on the full dynamic replacement
mattress
If a patient is assessed as requiring heel offloading in line with the heel care pathway:
If the full dynamic replacement mattress has an option to deflate heel cells this should be activated in line with Manufacturers guidance if required
Document this in the patient clinical record and site specific
Ensure the patient's heels are not resting on the base cells. If this happens reactivate the heel cells and provide a heel offloading device if clinically appropriate to do so
Other pressure relieving products
Repose products (Boots and wedge): use in line with the heel care pathway (Appendix 14).

Foot drop: Use the wedge if a patient already has foot drop. If the foot protector (boot) is used the heel will not be in the correct position to provide offloading. There is no evidence to suggest the use of the repose boot will prevent foot drop in patients at risk of this.
Use of the wedge in Critical Care / HDU
In this setting only the wedge can be used to replace a standard pillow for patients assessed as being at risk of developing pressure ulcers to their head or ears.
Z Flo positioner
To off load pressure over bony areas and including the ears if using for head positioning for the care of the prone patient
See Appendix  for further information on safe and effective use and cleaning of Repose products and Z flo positioner
Kerrapro pressure relieving pads to protect bony prominences
For patients who are assessed as being at high risk of developing pressure ulcers, or patients with category 1 pressure damage.
(See Appendix  for further information)
Keep moving - positioning and repositioning
Patients who are immobile are exposed to:
prolonged pressure and shear loads at contact sites between their body and the support surfaces they are on
sustained deformation in weight bearing soft tissue
Over time this may lead to development of pressure ulceration (Gefen 2020).
Repositioning reduces both the duration and magnitude of pressure over vulnerable parts of the body i.e. the bony prominences.
Repositioning frequency is determined by:
The patient's medical condition and location of existing pressure damage
nursed in the prone position
Mobility level and ability to reposition independently or not
Patient's ability to tolerate the new position
Comfort
Skin integrity (i.e. if pressure damage present or history or pressure damage) and tissue tolerance
Treatment objectives
Pressure relieving equipment type and specification in place
If the patient is seated or lying down
Nutritional status and requirements.
Assist the patient to reposition regardless of the support surface in situ if they are unable to do so independently.
Use appropriate, transferring and repositioning techniques, and manual handling equipment, to reposition a patient to prevent shearing and friction.
Use a full body slide sheet to reposition the patient if they are unable to reposition independently. The only exception is in the event of a medical emergency.
Patients who are able to should be advised to redistribute their weight with the frequency in line with their individualised care plan.
Maintain activity level, mobility, and a range of movement if appropriate for the patient.
In bed, use the 30-degree tilt side-lying position if a patient is unable to reposition themselves independently.
Repositioning regimes across the Trust
Ward based patients
35.1.1 During the day at least 2 hourly but adjust according to individual patient need and level of risk of pressure ulcer development.

35.1.2 Overnight (10pm-6am) consider extending repositioning frequency for patients who are unable to reposition themselves independently to reduce disruption to sleep. This should be based on the outcome of individual need and skin integrity assessed via skin inspection but should be no more than 4 hourly. This must be reviewed at each position change and regime / frequency increased accordingly to prevent pressure damage from occurring
Critical Care and High Dependency patients (HDU)
2 - 4 hourly for patients in Critical Care and High Dependency Units depending on the patient's medical condition (NICE. 2019. EPUAP. 2014).

However critically ill patients are often physiologically unstable and are therefore too unstable to turn. In addition these patients may exhibit haemodynamic and respiratory deterioration and instability for an extended time after repositioning. Such patients therefore cannot be repositioned frequently.

All patients in Critical Care / HDU should have their skin inspected at least every 24 hours, and if required, as an outcome of this inspection, their repositioning frequency should be adjusted / increased.
If patients are physiologically compromised and unstable this can prevent changes in position. Document this on the nursing observation chart and in the nursing documentation.
Caution: For all patients
Avoid rubbing the skin over bony prominences as this may cause pressure damage.
Avoid wherever possible positioning the patient on the area(s) of pressure damage

Limit head-of-bed elevation to 30 degrees for an individual on bed rest, unless contraindicated by medical condition and where possible encourage patients to sleep in a 30-to 40-degree side-lying position or flat in bed if this is appropriate to their medical condition.
Do not leave a patient on a bedpan longer than necessary
Do not position an individual directly on a pressure ulcer as far as is possible.

Do not apply heating devices (e.g. hot water bottles, heating pads, built in bed warmers) directly onto pressure ulcers. Heat increases the metabolic rate, induces sweating and decreases the tolerance of the skin pressure. When the body heat cannot dissipate, it will increase the risk of skin maceration and may impede healing.
Positioning and Repositioning the seated patient
Patients who sit for prolonged periods of time are at more risk of pressure ulcer development (Stephens and Bartley 2018).

When a patient is seated in a chair the weight of the body causes the greatest exposure to pressure to occur over the Ischial Tuberosities. As the loaded area in such cases is relatively small, the pressure will be high; therefore, without pressure relief, a pressure ulcer will occur quickly.
Select a posture that is acceptable to the patient, enables them to carry out their full range of functions, and minimises the pressure and extent of shear on the skin and soft tissues.
Ensure the patient is stable in the seating position and on the pressure relieving cushion if in place.
Ensure the patient's feet are well supported on the floor or a foot rest when sitting upright in a chair or wheel chair
Be aware that the addition of a pressure relieving cushion may alter the seat height and this must be taken into account.
For patients with pressure ulcers on the sacrum/coccyx or Ischial Tuberosity limit time sitting in a chair to three times a day in periods of 60 minutes or less.

Wherever possible and in line with their medical condition encourage the patient to offload pressure intermittently while sitting, e.g. by lifting themselves completely off the seat, sideways leans, forward tilts and leans, and standing.
Critically ill patients or spinal cord injury
If the patient's condition allows, and they can tolerate being moved, consider slow gradual turns or small shifts in position but recognise these do not replace turning.

Any person who is acutely ill and is at risk of developing a pressure ulcer should avoid uninterrupted sitting out of bed. The period of time should be defined in the individualised care plan but generally will not be more than two hours.
Labour Ward
Promote 2 hourly repositioning for patients during the stages of labour.
For patients who have an epidural in situ during labour encourage / support 2hrly movement / position change.
Heel care
If a patient cannot move their heels independently elevate their heels in line with the heel care pathway. (See Appendix  for pathway).
If using pillows:
place lengthwise if possible and ensure it extends the length of the calf to avoid areas of high pressure, particularly under the Achilles tendon.
do not fold as this can potentially cause pressure damage to a patient's lower legs.
ensure the patient's heels should not be lying on the pillow.
Ensure the patient's heels do not remain in contact with the mattress
Flex the knee slightly to avoid popliteal vein compression and increased risk of DVT.
Remove heel protector at each position change to enable heel skin inspection. Replace if clinically indicated as per the heel care pathway.
Ensure the patient's feet are not resting on the foot board or mattress pump fixators
Care of medical devices during positioning and repositioning
Avoid positioning the patient on any medical devices they may have (e.g. urinary catheter; lines; electrodes; probes etc.) when they are repositioned
Ensure the device is fixed in position correctly as required but also balance this with ensuring the fixation is not too tight as this itself may cause damage to the skin.
Use additional measures to reduce pressure and shear. For example; Foamlite under respiratory masks and oxygen tubing.
Where possible, do not position the device over a pressure ulcer or broken / damaged skin
Reposition the medical device at frequent intervals, if possible

Consider changing the device interface when delivering an intervention. For example, swap nasal prongs with a full-face mask for the delivery of respiratory support or replace ET ties with an Anchorfast as soon as clinically appropriate to do so
Reassessing a patient's repositioning regime

Reassess the repositioning regime if a patient's skin is not responding as expected with their repositioning regime. If appropriate to the patient's clinical condition, increase the repositioning frequency.
Document the revised regime in the patient's notes, along with the clinical rationale for adjusting the repositioning regime.
Positioning and Repositioning for the prone patient

Repositioning regime for the prone patient is based on individual patient need but usually approximately  hours prone, unless contraindicated due to medical condition, before repositioning to supine position.
Adhere to the procedures set out in the Prone SOP to ensure the patient is repositioned safely.
Pressure area care in prone
Adhere to the guidance set out by The Intensive Care Society when providing pressure area care for a patient in the prone position:
Ensure optimal positioning of pillows tailored to the patient's body habitus
Pressure areas should be meticulously checked
No direct pressure on the eyes
Ears not bent over
ETT not pressed against the corner of the mouth / lips
Nasogastric tube not pressed against nostril
Penis hanging between the legs with the catheter secured
Lines / tubing not pressed against the skin
When in prone repositioning of the arms in the swimmers position should be undertaken 2- 4 hourly and the patients head repositioned every 2 – 4 hours.
Mouth Ears Nose (M.E.N) checks must be undertaken at least 4 hourly but in line with patients medical condition.
Document the patients repositioning regime on the site specific Critical care bundle
Care of medical devices for the proned patient
Adhere to the procedures set out in the Prone SOP
Documentation
All patients should have a documented repositioning regime. This should take account of individual patient's circumstances.
Document:

The patient's repositioning frequency using site specific documentation (Southend and Broomfield Care Round documentation; Basildon site: SSKIN Bundle and Repositioning Charts; Critical Care SSKIN Bundle) and include this in the patient care plan / clinical record / post proning checklist
The position the patient is in at each position change

If the standard Trust approved repositioning regime is not appropriate for a patient following an individual patient assessment, or is contra-indicated due to their medical condition or circumstances:
Rationale for a revised repositioning regime; review this decision at least daily and on change of condition and on transfer
Consider:
installation of a higher specification mattress in line with the selection criteria (Appendix 12).
Incontinence
Provide correctly fitting continence pads for patients with continence needs. Avoid use of any other product to manage incontinence
Ensure continence products are not too tight to prevent device related skin damage
If a patient is incontinent of urine or faeces, keep the patient's skin clean, dry and well hydrated to prevent incontinence associated dermatitis.
Use a soap substitute to cleanse the skin following an episode of incontinence
use a barrier cream to protect the skin.
Follow the Incontinence Associated Dermatitis pathway (See Appendix 15)
Differentiating between a pressure ulcer and Incontinence
Associated Dermatitis (IAD)
The difference between pressure damage and moisture damage may be distinguished by cause:
location
shape
depth
Presence of necrosis
edges
colour
See Appendix 1 for support on correct identification of IAD from a pressure ulcer.
Nutrition
Complete the nutritional risk assessment tool for all patients within 24 hours of admission to the Trust and document outcome in the patient record.
Complete a nutritional care plan for patients if required as an outcome of the nutritional assessment.
Refer to the Dietitians as required/indicated as outcome of risk assessment.
Determine frequency of subsequent nutritional screening depending on outcome of initial screening
Refer patients prescribed oral nutritional supplements (ONS) to the Dietetics Department
Refer to Speech and Language Team (SALT) for patients who have swallowing issues.
Provide nutritional support to each individual with nutritional risk and pressure ulcer risk following the nutritional cycle
Ensure the patient is adequately hydrated
Enteral and parenteral nutrition may be necessary when oral nutrition is inadequate or not possible.
Giving information

Involve the patient wherever possible in line with their medical condition / level of consciousness, in the clinical decisions and care planning that impacts on their pressure ulcer prevention/ management.
Inform the patient if applicable, or their relatives, that the use of a medical device may cause pressure ulceration

Provide the patient, and if applicable, their relatives with information and education around pressure ulcer risk and prevention, and provide appropriate pressure ulcer information leaflets (Making an informed decision about preventing pressure damage MSE0025; Caring for your skin in hospital How to prevent pressure ulcers MSEPIL21001).
Declining care

If a patient with capacity declines any aspect of pressure area care – either prevention or management, a Health Care professional should discuss this decision and the implications of it with them to ensure they fully understand the implications of their decision. Document the outcome of this discussion in the patient's clinical record.

Provide the patient with the leaflet entitled ‘Making an informed decision about preventing pressure damage' (MSE0025). The patient should be given the opportunity to change their mind or their decision to decline care.
It would be considered good practice to recheck any decision to decline care during appropriate care planning discussions with the patient.
If there is any doubt that a patient no longer has capacity then the mental capacity assessment must be completed.
See Appendix  for Patient concordance to pressure area care advice pathway.
Prophylactic use of foam dressings to protect bony
prominences
Patients requiring long use of oxygen therapy
Apply foamlite in line with the device related pressure ulcer prevention pathway (Appendix 10).
Prone Care
Consider applying foam dressing to protect bony prominences when a patient is nursed prone due to extended periods of immobility (see Appendix 17).
Using prophylactic dressings
Use of the dressings should always be used alongside standard pressure ulcer prevention strategies (i.e. aSSKINg).
Skin inspection must be carried out before applying the dressing and at least once daily thereafter (by peeling back the dressings). Document the outcome clearly in the clinical record.
Before applying the dressing the skin must be clean and dry to ensure the dressing will adhere and remain in place.
Pressure Ulcer Management
Complete all pressure ulcer risks assessments as set out above in section 5
Follow the aSSKINg pathway and complete the site specific SSKIN care bundle twice daily
Document each pressure ulcer separately
Holistic Assessment
Complete a holistic assessment to include:
The patient's goals of care; if the patient is unable to advise, consult with the family or significant others.
past medical / social history – identifying any factors that may impact on wound healing
History of previous pressure ulcer(s)
Risk assessments:
Factors such as size and weight, smoking, concordance to care plans
Pain assessment and ensuring effective pain control is in place
Medication prescribed (this can impact wound healing)
Allergies (includes to dressings, tapes).
General skin assessment
Wound history
Patient preferences / choice
Pressure relieving equipment provision in line with patient need and circumstances
Level of mobility - if the patient is able to reposition independently or requires assistance to do so and the impact on manual handling
Patient acceptability, including manual handling and transfer
Impact of equipment on patient's independence and if there is an increased falls risk for example with an alternating mattress or cushion)
Factors which may affect healing (e.g. impaired perfusion, impaired sensation, systemic infection).
Vascular assessment in the case of heel pressure ulcers (e.g. history of claudication, and ankle brachial index or toe pressure).
Laboratory tests and x-rays as required.
Specific wound assessment
Assess each pressure ulcer on initial identification and at each dressing change to identify and address conditions at the wound bed.
The wound assessment should include:
Anatomical wound location
Pressure ulcer category

wound size taken at initial identification and at least weekly (length, depth and width measurements in centimetres using a disposable tape measure. Include areas of undermining / tunnelling and document undermining using the clock face method
document the position the patient is in when taking measurements to enable consistency of measurement.
exudate – type, colour, amount
type of tissue present – e.g. granulation, slough, necrosis
signs of wound infection (See Appendix 18).
condition of the wound margins and surrounding skin
medical photography
identifying local barriers to healing such as excess exudate, wound infection, necrotic tissue
Wound Reassessment
Undertake at each dressing change and at least weekly if the patient remains in hospital to:
monitor the appropriateness of the current wound care regime
respond to treatment changes following re-assessment
adjust the care plan as required
ensure the patient receives appropriate care based on a holistic assessment
document findings and any changes to care plan
Observe the pressure ulcer for developments which may indicate the need to change the treatment e.g. wound improvement or deterioration, more or less exudate, signs of infection.
Medical photography
Request, on initial assessment, or as soon as possible after admission. Obtain patient consent to wound photography and document in their nursing records.
If a patient lacks mental capacity, appropriate wound photography may be undertaken in the patient's best interest.
See Appendix  for Medical Photography pathway (Basildon and Southend site)
Cleansing
Cleanse the pressure ulcer and surrounding skin at each dressing change with normal saline, or portable water (water suitable for drinking) if no clinical signs of infection.

Consider using cleansing solutions with surfactants and / or antimicrobials to clean pressure ulcers with debris, confirmed infections, suspected infection or suspected high levels of bacterial colonisation.
Wound Infection
Identify patients considered to be at high risk of infection (see Appendix 18).

Take a deep wound swab in the presence of clinical signs of infection, and action outcome. Routine wound swabbing is not required in the absence of clinical signs of infection. Discuss the use of antibiotics with the Medical team.
Refer to Wound management policy
Dressing selection
Select an appropriate wound dressing in line with the Trust Wound Formulary considering patient preference wherever possible. Refer to the Wound Care policy
Follow manufacturer's instructions for use especially related to dressing change frequency.
Debridement

Decisions about the most appropriate form of debridement should be made by the Ward Medical staff, together with the Tissue Viability Team; only perform sharp debridement if deemed competent to do so (which is evidenced through completion of an accredited debridement course and completion of competencies), and following complete patient assessment.
Urgent surgical debridement may be required in the case of spreading sepsis or advancing cellulitis
Do not debride stable, hard, dry eschar in ischemic limbs or lower extremity pressure ulcers.
Heel pressure ulcers
Off load heels in line with the heel care pathway (Appendix 14).
Keep stable necrosis on the heel dry and intact. Refer to TVN Team prior to considering debridement of heel ulcer.
Pain assessment and management
Ensure all patients have a documented pressure ulcer pain assessment
Assess for pain

All patients should be asked to rate their pain according to pain score and pain relief offered/administered. An assessment of pain should include an assessment of body language and nonverbal clues e.g. change in activity, loss of appetite, guarding, grimacing and moaning.
Prevent pain
Use a hoist or transfer sheet i.e. sliding sheet, to minimise friction and / or shear when repositioning a patient, keeping bed linen smooth and unwrinkled.
Position the patient off of the pressure ulcer whenever possible.
Avoid postures which increase pressure, such as fowler's position greater than  degree or  degree side-lying position or the semi-recumbent position.
handle all wounds gently; irrigating and not rubbing unnecessarily during cleansing; and protecting the peri-wound skin.
Pain Management
Provide appropriate analgesia in line with the clinical need of the patient and including prior to dressing change as required, and document impact of this;
Refer to the pain team if a patient's pain remains uncontrolled.
Organise care delivery to ensure that it is coordinated with administration of analgesia and that minimal interruptions follow.
Encourage patients to request a “time out” during any procedure that causes pain.
Reduce pressure ulcer pain by keeping the wound bed covered and moist, and using a non-adherent dressing. (note: stable dry eschar is usually not moistened).
Use patient specific dressings less likely to cause pain and/or those likely to require less frequent dressing changes in line with the Wound Management Policy.
Encourage repositioning as a means to reducing pain.
Care planning for pressure ulcer prevention and management
Commence a preventative care plan within 6 hours of admission and review / update if a change in patient's medical condition or pressure ulcer status
Commence pressure ulcer care plan and document all care interventions.
Complete wound care template / electronic wound care plan
Review / update at least weekly or on change of wound condition
Methods for monitoring progress towards healing
Assess progress towards healing using the site specific wound assessment chart.
Use clinical judgement to assess signs of healing e.g. decreasing amount of exudate, change in size and improvement in tissue type.

Re-evaluate the pressure ulcer, the plan of care and the patient s condition if the pressure ulcer does not show progress towards healing  within 2 weeks (or as expected) given the patients overall condition and ability to heal. Consider referral as appropriate.
Transfer of a patient with a pressure ulcer
Ensure appropriate documentation regarding a patient's pressure ulcer status / care plan forms part of the handover process when a patient is transferred from one clinical ward /area to another.
Discharge of a patient with a pressure ulcer

66.8.1 Refer all housebound patients returning to their own home, or Residential Care Home who are identified as being at risk of, or with an existing pressure ulcer to the local Community Nursing Service.
66.8.2 If a patient is being discharged to a Nursing Home, ensure the Nursing Home staff are:
informed if a patient has, or is at risk of developing a pressure ulcer
informed of the appropriate pressure relieving equipment required
66.8.3 Provide comprehensive patient information relating to management of an existing pressure ulcer to the receiving Community Nursing team or Nursing Home depending on discharge destination.
66.8.4 Request appropriate pressure relieving equipment for use in the Community prior to patient discharge.
Safeguarding
Adult patients

67.1.1 It must be recognised that not all pressure ulcers in a vulnerable adult are the result of neglect. Pressure ulcers could also be acquired by people in their own home, possibly due to self-neglect or as a result of carers refusing help and advice.

67.1.2 With safeguarding neglect is defined as the deliberate withholding OR unintentional failure to provide appropriate and adequate care and support AND this has resulted in or is highly likely to result in a preventable pressure ulcer.

67.1.3 A pressure ulcer of category 2 (multiple) or category 3 and above should be considered as possible neglect. If a patient presents with a pressure ulcer which is assessed as category 2 (multiple), category 3 or 4, or unstageable ensure the patient will be safe on discharge ensuring that all appropriate assessments and care plans are in place to deliver continuity of care. If the patient is a current inpatient review the pressure ulcer history.
67.1.4 Safeguarding referral for patients sustaining a pressure ulcer(s) whilst in our care will be considered within the Harm Free Care Panel process.
67.1.5 Any patients admitted with pressure damage should be assessed and considered for a safeguarding referral if neglect / omission is suspected.

67.1.6 In order to determine whether a safeguarding concern should be raised please review the Safeguarding Adults policy or seek support by contacting your local safeguarding team or clinical site manager out of hours.
Children
67.2.1 Refer to Safeguarding Team if there are any pressure ulcer related concerns. Refer to the Children Safeguarding policy.
Tissue Viability Referral

Refer all patients with Category 3,4, unstageable pressure ulcer, deep tissue injury and if a patient has multiple category 2 pressure ulcers to the Tissue Viability team via electronic referral, in line with the Tissue Viability referral criteria.
Education and Training
The Trust provides in-house training in pressure ulcer prevention and management.

This training is carried out by the Tissue Viability Nurses. The frequency and content of training will be in line with the needs of the clinical directorates. This will be identified by both the Tissue Viability Team and the Clinical Care Groups.

Education programmes for the prevention of pressure damage will be structured, organised and comprehensive and made available at all levels of clinical staff working within the Trust including Bank and Agency staff

All nursing staff will have access to training sessions relating to the prevention of pressure damage. The education programme will be updated on a regular basis by the Tissue Viability Team based on best evidence practice.
SSKIN Champions

The Trust supports the role of aSSKINg Champions. Each clinical area and Ward will appoint at least one Health Care Assistant and one Registered Nurse to represent their Ward/clinical area. They will act as a link between their ward/clinical area and the Tissue Viability Nurses.
The aSSKINg Champion will act as a role model for their colleagues and support and in relation to pressure ulcer care will promote compliance with expected standards of set pressure ulcer care.
Training requirements
Outline training requirements or if not appropriate state:
71.1.1 Type here
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Incidents of hospital acquired pressure ulcers have RCAs undertaken to
ascertain level of harm to ascertain shared learning and if they meet the SI criteria
Annual audit of compliance audit will assess documentation of risk assessments, body maps, treatments and interventions

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Harm Free Care Panel, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Pressure Ulcer Policy guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Harm Free Care panel of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 22)
References

Gebhardt, C. Bliss, M. (1994). Preventing pressure ulcers in orthopaedic patients – is prolonged chair nursing detrimental? Journal Tissue Viability Vol 4 (2). Pages 51-54.
Clark. M., Defloor. T. (2004) The prevalence of pressure ulcers in Europe. In: Clarke M (Ed.), Advances in Tissue Viability. Quay Books.
Dealey, C. Posnett, J. Walker, A. (2012). The cost of pressure ulcers in the United Kingdom. Journal of Wound Care. Vol 21(6) pages 261-2, 264, 266

Pressure Ulcer Prevention Quick reference guide (2014) European Pressure ulcer Advisory Panel  www.epuap.org/

Jones, I. Tweed, C. Marron, M. (2001). Pressure area care in infants and children: Nimbus® Paediatric system. British Journal of Nursing, Vol 10 (12) pages 789 - 795
Langemo, D.K,. Melland, H,. Hanson, D,. Olson, B & Hunter, S. (2000) The lived experience of having a pressure ulcer: a qualitative analysis Advanced skin care vol 13 pages 225-235.
NHS Midlands and East stop the pressure campaign www.eoe.nhs.uk
NHS Improvement (2018). Pressure Ulcers: revised definition and measurement

Nicosia, G., Gliatta, A.E., Woodbury, G., Houghton, P.E. (2007) The effect of pressure relieving surfaces on the prevention of heel ulcers in a variety of settings: a meta-analysis. International Wound Journal Vol (4). Pages 197-207.
Nursing and Midwifery Council (2008).  The code: Standards of conduct, performance and ethics for nurses and midwives. www.nmc-org.uk
Ousey, K. (2009) Heel ulceration – an exploration of the issues. Journal of Orthopaedic Nursing. Pages 97-104 Vol 13.
Parnham, A (2012). Pressure ulcer risk assessment and prevention in children. Nursing Young People and Children. Vol 24 (2).pages 24-29
Phillips J, 1997. Access to clinical education – Pressure Sores. London. Churchill Livingstone.
Stechmiller, J.K (2010). Understanding the role of nutrition and wound healing. Nutrition in Clinical Practice. Vol 25 (1). Pages 61-68

Vowden, P & Vowden K.R (2009) The prevalence, management, equipment provision and outcome for patients with pressure ulceration identified in a wound care survey within one English health care district. Journal of Tissue Viability vol 18 pages 20-29.
Willock, J (2000). Pressure sores in children – the acute hospital perspective. Journal of Tissue Viability Vol 2 (10). Pages 59-62
World Union of Wound Healing Socities (WUWHS) Consensus Document. Role of dressings in pressure ulcer prevention. Wounds International, 2016. Available to down load www.woundsinternational.com
Wounds UK Consensus document (2017). Recognising, managing and preventing deep tissue injury (DTI). London: Wounds UK 2017 available to download from www.wounds-uk.com
Zeller. J.L. Lynm, C. Glass, R.M. (2006). Pressure Ulcers. JAMA. 2006; Vol 296 (8) Page 1020.
(Manual Handling Operation Regulation (MHOR) 1992:
Prevention and Treatment of Pressure Ulcers: Quick Reference Guide (2014) European Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel
Pressure Ulcers: prevention and management of pressure ulcers (2014). NICE Clinical guidelines.
Appendix 1: Click here for Pressure Ulcers vs Moisture Associated Skin Damage
Appendix 2: Explanation of Extrinsic factors

table_items.text: Pressure: the exertion of continuous force on an area; its force is usually vertical in nature resulting in a circular shaped area of damage directly over a bony prominence. Pressure damage occurs when the skin and other tissues are directly compressed between bone and another surface, the capillary blood flow is cut off and over time the skin will die. The relationship between pressure and tissue damage is dependent on two characteristics: the intensity of the pressure and the duration of the pressure. Prevention therefore should be targeted at removing or relieving one or other.

Shear: This force occurs when tissues are wrenched in opposite directions such as when reclining, or sliding down a bed: external skin stays in contact with the chair but internally the tissues are sliding down resulting in disruption or angulations' of capillary vessels. Tissue damage caused by shear is usually 'teardrop' shaped caused by the pull on the skin

Friction: This is no longer included within the definition of a pressure ulcer. However friction occurs when the skin has rubbed against another surface. This most often produces a blister or 'scuffed' area. It may result from poor moving and handling.

data.text: Appendix 3: Explanation of Intrinsic factors

table_items.text: These include: general medical condition; previous history of tissue damage; levels of mobility; levels of consciousness; moisture to the skin; continence issues; posture; pain extremes of age; malnutrition and dehydration; sensory impairment; acute, chronic or terminal illness; vascular disease; neurological deficit; trauma; medication lower extremity oedema

data.text: Appendix 4: Click here for European Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel pressure ulcer Categorisation system
Appendix 5: Deep Tissue Injury (DTI)

A DTI starts deep within tissue and does not usually become apparent until about 24–72 hours after the event that caused the tissue damage (Black et al, 2016). Such events include lying immobile on a hard surface, e.g. on the floor after a fall that has resulted in unconsciousness or that is due to a stroke, or experiencing a period of poor tissue perfusion, e.g. during cardiothoracic surgery. In keeping with pain being a predictor of PUs (Smith et al, 2017), conscious and sensate patients may complain of pain before the appearance of the physical signs of DTI.

In patients with light-toned skin: DTI presents about 24–72 hours after initiation as a demarcated area of purple or maroon skin, often likened to a bruise. The purple or maroon area may be surrounded by an area of erythema. The discoloured area and erythema are nonblanchable (Black et al, 2016).
When palpated, the affected area may feel:
Firmer or hardened (indurated) due to stiffening of dead or dying muscle tissue or
Softened (‘boggy' or ‘mushy') as the damaged tissue starts to break down and/or
Warmer or cooler than surrounding areas (Gefen, 2009).
In patients with dark-toned skin: the skin of affected areas may be darker or lighter, and palpation to detect changes in tissue texture or temperature is particularly important (Black et al, 2016).
A retrospective review of patients with darkly pigmented skin found that the most commonly described presentation of DTIs was purple discolouration of intact skin (Sullivan, 2014).
Patients who are conscious and have sensation in the affected area may complain of discomfort or pain, and/or find palpation uncomfortable or painful

When assessing the temperature of the skin, it is important to consider whether the area has been in contact with or covered by bedding or clothing or has been exposed (i.e. it is warmer or cooler for extrinsic reasons), the ambient temperature, and the temperature of the assessor's hands.

After a further 24–48 hours, the outer layer of the skin of the affected area may appear dry, start to peel or form a shallow blister (known as epidermal lift or sloughing). The full thickness of the skin may also lift or blister, and breaks in the skin can occur to reveal a purple, maroon, black or white wound bed (Black et al, 2016). In patients with dark toned skin, blistering and skin breaks may be the first signs noticed of a DTI (Sullivan, 2014). Blisters may become filled with liquefied necrotic tissue and look like blood blisters.

Eventually a hard, blackened surface (eschar) may develop. When this finally sloughs or is debrided it will reveal the extent of the tissue damage and possibly a deep open wound. In some cases, sloughing of the eschar reveals intact or healed skin.
Although the appearance of DTI is often described as a bruise, it should be noted that a DTI does not go through the colour changes typical of a bruise as it resolves
Natural history and evolution of DTI

Although full clarification of the natural history of DTIs and the factors that influence it is still to be established, it is clear that the outcome is variable. Some DTIs can deteriorate very rapidly to become large, deep open wounds despite best practice management. However, not all DTIs evolve or deteriorate. A proportion of DTIs will remain static for quite some time (anecdotally up to several months) or will resolve without forming an open wound (cited in Wounds Uk 2017, Richbourg et al, 2011).
Wounds UK Consensus document (2017).
Appendix 6:  Click here for DTI pathway
Appendix 7: Click here for aSSKINg framework Appendix 8: Click here for Pressure Ulcer Pathway
Appendix 9: Patients vulnerable to pressure ulcer development

table_items.text: Patients at risk of pressure ulcer development include those who:

Are seriously ill In Critical Care Have spinal cord compression/injury Are neurologically compromised Are immobile or have impaired mobility Have impaired nutrition Have poor posture, or use equipment (seating/bed) which provides inadequate pressure relief. The elderly or very young Recent surgery Have diabetes Have peripheral Vascular disease Have orthopaedic conditions

data.text: Pressure ulcers can develop in any area of the body. In adults damage usually occurs over bony prominences. Heels are the second most common site for pressure ulcers and are particularly at risk of pressure damage due to their anatomy.
Presentation in infants and children is more likely to occur on the occipital area or ears.

table_items.text: Vulnerable at risk areas for patients include:

Sacrum Heels Ankles Ischial tuberosities Femoral trochanters Elbows Shoulders Temporal and occipital regions of the skull Parts of the body where pressure friction or shear are likely to be exerted Body parts in contact with medical devices or tight clothing Areas of the body affected by moisture damage and incontinence Areas of the body affected by anti-embolic stockings
Factors that may exacerbate pressure ulcer development

Moisture: wet skin is more prone to damage and requires extra care. The source of excess moisture due to incontinence, perspiration or wound drainage should be identified, managed or eliminated where possible Excessive washing with alkaline soap should be avoided, consider using a soap substitute as an alternative. No sting barrier creams or films may be used to protect surrounding skin if broken or macerated.

Appendix 18: Identifying high Risk Patients with Infection in Pressure Ulcers
High risk of likelihood of an infection in a pressure ulcer includes:
Presence of necrotic tissue
Presence of foreign bodies
Depth and size of ulcer
Length of time present
Location – i.e. frequently contaminated
Diabetes
Malnutrition
Immuno-supressed patients
Poor tissue perfusion
Patients with auto-immune conditions
Signs of infection are set out below in Table 1 Table 1 signs and symptoms of Infection

table_items.text: Subtle signs of local infection early stage of local infection

Extending in duration with or without +/- erythema Lymphangitis, Crepitus Wound breakdown / dehiscence with or without satellite lesions Malaise/lethargy or nonspecific general deterioration Loss of appetite Inflammation, swelling of lymph glands
Severe sepsis Septic shock Organ failure Death

Hypergranulation Bleeding friable granulation tissue Bridging and pocketing in granulation tissue Wound breakdown and enlargement Delayed healing beyond expectations New or increasing pain Increasing malodour
Erythema Local warmth Oedema Delayed wound healing beyond normal expectation New or increasing pain Increasing Malodour Purulent discharge Epithelial bridging & or pocketing in granulation tissue
