Pressure ulcer prevention and management policy / MSEPO-21153 / 1.0
Page  of
Appendix 20: Other pressure relieving products
Other pressure relieving products Repose products

Repose products (boot and wedge) are an effective aide for prevention and management of heel pressure ulcers (see the Heel care pathway). The wedge can also be used as a pillow for patients assessed via the risk assessment process as being at risk of developing pressure ulcers to their head or ears.

The Wedge: works by immersion (sinking into the product) and envelopment (hugging the body). By spreading the load over a greater surface area, these principles apply to all areas of the body where the product is used. Whilst there is a lack of specific evidence regarding use of the repose wedge to replace a standard pillow, experience locally has been shown it to be clinically effective.
The Repose Wedge covered with a sheet can be used as an alternative to the boot for heel management

Effectiveness of the products where there are secretions: The presence of secretions will not stop the immersion and envelopment and therefore pressure redistribution. However if secretions are not managed effectively they could have an impact on the skin from a moisture perspective.  The wedge should be covered with a sheet but in addition, in line with the Intensive Care Society guidelines, an absorbent pad can be placed under the mouth to absorb any secretions, if this is required
The repose products are available as a prone kit. Cleansing the repose products

Repose products are easily cleaned using soap and water and/or clinical wipes (Appendix 13). This makes it suitable from an infection prevention perspective for use with highly exudating wounds, and where the dressing is not managing the exudate...
Foot drop
The wedge should be used if a patient already has foot drop. If the foot protector (boot) is used the heel will not be in the correct position to provide offloading.
There is no evidence available to suggest the use of the repose boot will prevent foot drop in patients at risk of this.
Prophylactic use of foam dressings to protect bony prominences and the Z flo positioner The European Pressure Ulcer Panel virtual meeting (September 2020) drew attention to
use of fluidised positioners (Z flo positioner) to protect the head and face from injury whilst prone
prophylactic use of foam dressings to protect bony prominences,

Evidence in the literature, and anecdotally from clinicians working in Critical Care, supports these prevention strategies (World Union World Healing Societies consensus document 2016; Peko et al 2020; Beckman presentation at EPUAP virtual meeting September 2020).
Z Flo positioner
Within Critical Care Unit / HDU the Z Flo positioner is available to use as part of the regime of care to prevent pressure damage to a patient's face and head whilst in the prone position.

Z Flo positioner is made from viscoelastic material with shape memory properties; it can be moulded to shape to meet the individual need. The product retains its shape. When repositioning is required the positioner can be remoulded into a new shape to support the patient in the new position.
The positioner can be used to:
Redistribute pressure from body weight forces over a greater surface area via immersion and envelopment
Off load pressure over bony areas and including the ears if using for head positioning
A poster is available on Critical Care / HDU to support effective use of the Z flo positioner (see Appendix 2)
Foam dressings

For patients in Critical Care Mepilex border is the Trust's dressings of choice to protect bony prominences from pressure damage. This is particularly useful when a patient is nursed in the prone position due to extended periods of immobility.
The use of these dressings should always be used alongside standard pressure ulcer prevention strategies (i.e. aSSKINg).
Skin inspection must be carried out before applying mepilex border and at least once daily thereafter (by peeling back the dressings), and the outcome clearly documented in the clinical record.
Before applying dressings the skin must be clean and dry to ensure the dressing will adhere and remain in place.
A poster is available to support appropriate use and application of the dressing (see Appendix 3).
Foamlite

Sometimes DRPUs can be very hard to prevent especially if the device forms an essential part of the patient's treatment. An example of this is non-invasive ventilation masks. DRPUs are most frequently, but not exclusively, associated with use of respiratory devices such as BiPAP and CPAP masks.

Across the Trust, a device related pressure ulcer prevention pathway is in place to help reduce DRPUs specifically for patients requiring oxygen therapy via non-invasive ventilation systems, and nasal cannula. Foamlite is the dressing used in the pathway.

This pathway should be adhered to, wherever possible, and in line with the patient's medical condition. If a Foamlite dressing is used (as set out in the pathway), this should be documented in the patient's record.
Kerrapro pressure relieving pads

Kerrapro pressure reducing pads are made for 100% medical grade silicone and are specifically designed to help protect skin over bony prominences. They are designed to dissipate pressure and protect intact or recently healed skin from pressure damage. They are available in a range of shapes and thicknesses.
Indications for using Kerrapro pressure relieving pads:
For patients who are assessed as being at high risk of developing pressure ulcers, or patients that already present with category 1 pressure damage.
Appropriate use:
Inappropriate use:
Appendix 21: Manual Handling useful information

Pressure ulcers can develop from using manual handling devices. Therefore it is important that a comprehensive risk assessment of a moving and handling task is carried out, as this will identify any hazards posed by the activity. (Manual Handling Operation Regulation (MHOR) 1992: Royal College of Nursing 1999).
Some hazards may arise through the use of equipment and techniques used. These hazards include:
Equipment/Techniques; Possible Hazard
Chairs; patients inability to get out of the chair
Seat surface may cause uneven distribution of pressure, Perspiration or friction
(Patient weight & size may cause pressure on arms and hips if too large for chair size)
Wheelchairs; Maybe ill-fitting causing pressure
Tissue damage maybe caused by contact with protrusions such as footplates
Beds; Confinement to bed: patient unable to change position:
Shower/Commode Chairs; patient seated on chair for long periods
Inappropriate transfer of the patient from one surface to another may cause friction damage.
Transfer Boards; Bare skin on board surface: Composition of the board may cause grazing: Clothing may be pulled against the skin. Feet or head may be off the end of the sliding surface causing drag.
Sliding Sheets/Low Friction Rollers; Fabric may crumple against the skin: Feet and/or arms may drag as buttocks move
Hoist/Slings; ill-fitting sling may cause pressure against the skin
Sling left in place may cause pressure against the skin
Incorrect sling for the task
Insufficient lift causing client to be dragged
Fabric of sling may be too rough

The safe use of equipment involves achieving the transfer as intended and preventing unnecessary injury to patient in the process and this includes acknowledging the potential for tissue damage that can occur during these activities. Further specialist advice maybe sought from the Health and Safety Department.
